g.text: Characterization, and Li Ion Transport Properties of Garnet-Type Al-
Institute of Physical Chemistry and Electrochemistry, and ZFM
Center for Solid State Chemistry and New Materials, Leibniz
University Hannover, Callinstr. 3a, D-30167 Hannover, Germany
Institute of Mineralogy, Leibniz University Hannover, Callinstr. 3, D-30167 Hannover, Germany
Various polycrystalline samples of Al-doped garnet-like Li
crystallizing with cubic symmetry were synthesized from the binary oxides Li
. The synthesis of phase pure samples was carried out following a two-step
preparation route. It consists of an activation step by high-energy ball milling and a
subsequent annealing step at elevated temperatures. The synthesis route chosen allows the
precise adjustment of the cationic ratios, leading to a garnet which is best described by the
. As conﬁrmed by X-ray powder diﬀraction and
magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), at low Al concentrations the
ions act as an aliovalent dopant by replacing three Li
ions are progressively replaced by Al ions. It turned out
that, in particular, the substitution of La
modiﬁcation of the garnet and greatly aﬀects the corresponding Li ion dynamics. The latter
has been probed by both impedance and
Li NMR spectroscopy. The high ion conductivity (10
not only depend on the stoichiometry and the annealing conditions chosen but also on the exact kind of Al distribution on the
Li-containing garnet-type oxides are considered to act as
promising fast ion-conducting electrolytes in, e.g., all-solid-state
lithium-ion batteries. These are expected to be one of the key
technologies to store electrical energy in the next years.
Hence, previously a number of studies have been published
which are concerned with profound investigations of the
property relations of crystalline garnet-type oxides
14). In particular, the garnet with the
cubic symmetry attracted large interest. In contrast to the
tetragonal counterpart, which is characterized by an ionic bulk
the samples with cubic symmetry investigated so far show an
Currently, much work is in progress to
identify the origins causing the high lithium ion conductivity.
The results of recently published studies provide strong
rated into LLZ during the high-temperature synthesis
procedure using alumina crucibles, at least stabilize the cubic
ison, the preparation of Al-free LLZ usually leads to the
formation of the tetragonally distorted garnet.
noting that Al-free tetragonal LLZ transforms into the cubic
us showed quite recently, the phase transformation is not
accompanied by a signiﬁcant enhancement of the ionic
does not lead to the enhancement of the Li
observed for some of the samples studied (see also ref 24). As
already discussed by Geiger et al., at low dopant levels the
incorporation of Al may inﬂuence the number fraction of Li
vacancies and, thus, the Li ion conductivity. Further
investigations focusing on the role Al plays in inﬂuencing the
Li ion dynamics parameters might be useful to understand and,
in the best case, to improve Li ion transport in LLZ.
Here, we present a systematic study addressing in depth the
eﬀects of Al incorporation on both structural and dynamic
properties of LLZ. For this purpose we developed a soft
synthesis route avoiding high temperatures and enabling the
precise adjustment of the contents of all cations in LLZ.
similar investigations. However, the necessary temperatures for
the latter procedures are still higher than the temperatures
needed for the synthesis routine described here.
In the present study, various polycrystalline samples of cubic
LLZ with diﬀerent amounts of Al were prepared from mixtures
